reasoning: The question targets a key hinge in the paper’s anti-WAM-convergence argument (especially the realism+internalism/externalism discussion): if powerful actors systematically engage in “motivational avoidance,” then governance-by-moral-advice and convergence stories weaken substantially; if not, they strengthen—so strategy could change a lot (high cruciality, strong decision hook). It is fairly paper-specific because it directly probes a named mechanism the essay relies on (avoidance of motivating moral truth), though versions of it also arise in broader moral psychology/political economy (so not maximal specificity). It’s only moderately tractable because the relevant target class is “powerful actors” in highly novel post-AGI conditions; still, partial progress is possible via proxies (elite decision-making studies, motivated reasoning/identity-protective cognition experiments, historical cases of willful ignorance, organizational incentive analyses). Clarity is decent but not perfect: ‘learn vs believe vs internalize,’ what counts as ‘moral reflection/advice,’ and the unit (‘how often’) need operational definitions. Minimal dead weight.
title: Frequency of motivated avoidance in moral belief adoption
